adjective.description: Actual; precise (used to emphasize the exact identity of a particular person or thing)
examples: he might be phoning her at this very moment

phrases: My friend was not very impressed and it was obvious that he did not want to know anything about Islam.
Behind us stood a few of those from the most extremist of the settlers, not very satisfied that we had arrived to Hebron.
Sadly for Rogers, he missed the not very difficult conversion, and those were the crucial two points.
origin: Middle English (as an adjective in the sense real, genuine): from Old French verai, based on Latin verus true.
